alert.note: Alert for Delta (Colorado) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS GrandJunction (Western Colorado and Eastern Utah)
info.headline: Flood Advisory issued May 17 at 6:13PM MDT until May 19 at 6:00PM MDT by NWS GrandJunction
info.description: ...The Flood Advisory continues for the following rivers in Colorado... Gunnison River at Delta affecting Delta County. .Warm Spring temperatures will continue melt the snow pack and lead to lead to strong runoff conditions. ...FLOOD ADVISORY FOR SNOWMELT NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL FRIDAY EVENING... * WHAT...Flooding caused by snowmelt continues. * WHERE...Gunnison River at Delta. * WHEN...Until Friday evening. * IMPACTS...At 10.0 feet, water reaches the base of the berms in the Four Seasons River Inn RV Park and Riverwood Mobile Home Park, water nears the top of the berm separating Confluence Park from the Gunnison River, and the right river bank across from Confluence Park may be flooded. At 10.5 feet, the river gage site becomes flooded. At 11.0 feet, flooding of low-lying agricultural land is possible, while portions of Confluence Park in the vicinity of the Gunnison River is expected to flood. In addition, some hiking trails near the confluence with the Uncompahgre River may become inundated by water. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 5:15 PM MDT Wednesday the stage was 8.8 feet. - Forecast...The river will oscillate below flood stage with a maximum value of 10.1 feet Saturday afternoon. - Action stage is 9.5 feet. - Flood stage is 12.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood && Fld Observed Forecasts (6 pm MDT) Location Stg Stg Day/Time Thu Fri Sat Gunnison River Delta 12.0 8.8 Wed 5 pm MDT 9.6 9.9 10.1 &&
info.instruction: If you encounter a flooded roadway, turn around and find an alternative route. If you are in the advisory area, remain alert to possible flooding or the possibility of the advisory being upgraded to a warning. Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law enforcement and request they pass this information to the National Weather Service when you can do so safely.
